data.title: EH watchdog is triggered after sleep/wakeup
data.body:
Since two days I'm always seeing the following alert when arriving at home or work:

![2017-08-15_23-03-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/29353980-5185501a-826c-11e7-8874-ed7fd27ce997.png)
 
The dev console shows this:
![2017-08-16_10-19-26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/29354033-7f69c448-826c-11e7-8628-1c4e5ca8316a.png)

I never had any problems with VS Code previously. Now with the watch dog timer I have ;-)

Could it be that we have to consider sleep/wakeup events so that your timeout logic knows that the sleep phase is not an indication for the EH being unresponsive?

data.title: Usability request: Options for the Find/Replace-fields when opening Replace dialog
data.body:
Almost every time I want to replace something, I press Ctrl + H and find that I need to step backwards with Shift + Tab to get to the find part of the dialog, enter what I want to be replaced, then step back to the replace part and enter what I want to replace it with. (Technically speaking I could enter that first but it's a unintuitive).

Maybe there already is a way to do this but I haven't been able to find it. 

I'd like some kind of option or possibility that whenever I hit Ctrl +  H with nothing selected, I start the process "from scratch" - with typing in what I want in the find textfield.


Here's an example of what I mean:

![vscode_replace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1578924/29353323-144ea202-826a-11e7-90c5-bb1c69b5ffa7.gif)

I'd also like an option to _always_ start in the find textfield even if I have something selected to be able to modify it first, or copy it to the clipboard so I can paste it in the replace part. 

I'd also like an option to have the same text in both the find and in the replace-part. It's common for me to want to replace "LONG STRING THING 1" with "LONG STRING THING 2" and right now I have to type all of that in again or ensure that it's in my clipboard.

data.title: 'Extension host terminated unexpectedly' when resuming work
data.body:
This morning, when starting to work again, I bring back the VSCode window to the front. It shows the message: 'Extension host terminated unexpectedly', but all seems to work well.

Can it be that the timer expired while my machine was in sleep mode?

data.title: Move search function to use Promise interface
data.body:
Draft to fix #20650

Initial draft of changes for moving the `search` function inside FileSearch and
TextSearch modules to ause a promise interface instead of callbacks.

I have a couple of problems with the changes I made:

1. The `complete` action's object shape is very different from that of
   `progress`. So much so that the usage doesn't feel natural to me.

   As @roblourens pointed out, may be it's time to have different interfaces
   for text and file search.

2. This doesn't clean up code related to ripgrepsearch yet.

data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open terminal
2. paste the following text into the terminal:

"\xff\x8c\x90\xc1\x6a\xeb\x30\x10\x45\xf7\xfe\x8a\xbb\x73x1e\x3c\xd3\x0f\xf0\x4a\xb5\x27\xc1\x20"

The way I originally triggered this was doing a diff of some encoded binary data.  This was a tiny piece of a 1000 character string.  Originally I thought it was a long line problem, but evidently not.

Note this happens with the default terminal and with iTerm2 .  Not sure about other OSes.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

Yes

data.title: Filter out impossible types in autocompletion for TypeScript comparison based on compared type
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Version 1.15.0 (1.15.0)
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.6 (16G29)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Here is a sample file, never mind the stupidity or validity of the subject:

```
enum HorseType {
    Striped = 'striped',
    Plain = 'plain',
    Green = 'green'
}

interface Horse {
    type: HorseType
}

interface Zebra extends Horse {
    type: HorseType.Plain
    zooName: string
}

interface DomesticHorse extends Horse {
    type: HorseType.Plain
    horseName: string
}

type NormalHorse = Zebra | NormalHorse

const testZebra: Zebra = {
    zooName: 'Ueno Zoo'
}

function horseIsZebra(horse: NormalHorse): boolean {
    return horse.type === HorseType.<CURSOR_HERE>
}
```
2. The auto completion that shows up at `<CURSOR_HERE>` shows all the three options for `HorseType` even though we know that `horse` being of type `NormalHorse` can only have the values `Plain` or `Zebra`, not `Green`. So, `Green` should be filtered out in this case.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [Feature Request] Add drag and drop for contributed tree views

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We've been using new Tree View API to provide structured view of F# projects - in F# project files needs to be ordered according to compilation order so this additional view gives users better information about their project. We also include in the view list of project references, and assembly references so it's really similar to the Visual Studio solution explorer.

It looks like following:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5427083/29336346-be4fc22a-820d-11e7-9ea6-abe8b185989d.png)

As I've mentioned - ordering of files is really important for the F# projects, and we provide couple of helper commands to manage it (move file up/down etc).  Those commands work more or less, but I don't think it's best UX.
I think it would be super nice if users had ability to use normal drag and drop to manipulate the order - just as they are able to manipulate files in normal file explorer (drag and drop files to move them to subfolder for example)

data.title: fixing c++ bugs in javascript - feature request
data.body:
Emscripten is a very good project to port c/c++ projects to javascript,
there is a feature called Manual print debugging, which prints out the line number of the given c++ code in the ported javascript code.

http://kripken.github.io/emscripten-site/docs/porting/Debugging.html

My feature request sounds crazy, but there is a valid reason.

Because of emscripten you can debug ported javascript code from c++,
what i would like to achieve, to make changes in javascript and automatically converted back to c++.

I think that functionality can empower the free source world.

Especially when you have a badly written aging project like ffmpeg and you would like to find bugs in it,
so you can use emscripten debug it in the browser and convert back the changes into c++.

So any freesource project which misses manpower can get free hands quickly as javascript is a well known and easy to use language for everyone.

There are special cases, but to check and validate an encoder algorithm make it more efficient programatically can be a valid reason to use that technic. If you would be able to read the algorithm in a better way and debug in a better way, you can get an idea to write far better algorithm than the heavily patented mpeg h264 and aac. (I think it's a common problem in every browsers nowadays)

Not to mention c++ projects, which has been ended because lots of resources was needed to fix bugs further. (Osmosis is a good example on open street map - everybody is using it as a google alternative, but the osmisis itself is in 0.55 version, and finished the development after 2016)
